abstract.p: The short description should follow the following patterns:

ul.li: Use natural language whenever possible. This is critical for elements that are shared with LwDITA.
Be sure and describe what something is â€“ or the primary function that it serves. For example, A short description describes the purpose or main point of a topic.

section.title: Usage information
section.p: Use this section to provide additional information that is necessary for a reader to understand the element. For example:
section.lq: The dita element cannot be specialized. It is provided as a container that can manage any sequence of any type of topic. Topic nesting rules can be configured in the document-type shell.
section.p: Convenience elements should have paragraphs that contain the following information:
section.lq: The linktitle element is a convenience element. It is equivalent to a titlealt element with title-role set to linking.

section.title: Rendering expectations
section.p: Use this section to explain any rendering expectation for the element. In general, rendering expectation are about how the content will show up "on the glass." For example:
section.lq: Processors SHOULD render the content of the shortdesc element as the initial paragraph of the topic.
section.p: Be sure to distinguish between rendering and formatting expectations; formatting expectations go in a non-normative appendix topic.

section.title: Processing expectations
section.p: Use this section to explain processing expectations for the element. In general, processing expectations are about X. For example:
section.lq: When a shortdesc element occurs in a DITA map, it overrides the short description provided in the topic for the purpose of generating map-based link previews. It does not replace the shortdesc in the rendered topic itself. This means that generated map-based links to this topic will use the short description from the map for any link previews provided with the link, while the rendered topic continues to use the short description inside the topic.

section.title: Specialization hierarchy
section.p: Use the following type of wording:
section.lq: The linktitle element is specialized from titlealt. It is defined in the alternative-titles domain module.

section.title: Attributes
section.p: Content to be added by Robert Anderson.

example.title: Example
example.p: This section should have a title of either Example or Examples, depending on whether there are multiple examples.
(If there are multiple examples) The section should be introduced with a paragraph; use the following phrasing:
example.lq: This section contains examples of how the myElement element can be used.
example.p: Each example should be in a fig element with a title. Each code sample should be introduced with a paragraph that explains what the code sample does and its relevance; we use the following phrasing: The following code sample shows ...

The code samples should be realistic, if it all possible. The relevant elements in the code sample might be highlighted (bold) to draw the readers attention. Code samples should be indented four spaces.
If content is "snipped" from the code sample, it should be indicated with <!-- ... -->.
